THIS CRIMINAL MISC. CASE HAVING COME UP FOR ADMISSION ON
09.01.2019, THE COURT ON THE SAME DAY PASSED THE FOLLOWING:

Bags ial
Cr1.MC.No. 8736 of 2018 2 2011KER/1240
ORDER

This petition is filed under Section 482 of the Code of Criminal
Procedure (“the Code” for brevity) with a prayer to quash the
proceedings pending against the petitioners.

2. The 2™ respondent is the daughter of the 1 respondent.
The 1* petitioner and the 2™ respondent were in love. As their
relationship was not approved by the 1* respondent, they eloped. The
1* respondent set the law in motion and based on his information,
Crime No.661/2011 was registered on 21.07.2011. After completion
of investigation, the final report has been laid before the Court of
Session. The case is now pending as S.C. No.1157 of 2013 on the file
of the II Additional Sessions Court, Thiruvananthapuram.

3. Before the submission of the final report, the family
members got together and decided to solemnize the marriage between
the lovers. Consequently, on 8.9.2012, the marriage was held as is
evident from Annexure-C certificate. Two children were born to them
and this fact is evident from Annexures-D and E birth certificates. The
respondents i and 2 have filed separate affidavits before this Court
stating that the entire disputes have resolved between the parties and
they have no grievance. It is in the aforesaid backdrop that this

Beer

op
Cr1.MC.No. 8736 of 2018 3 2011KER/1240
petition is filed seeking to quash the proceedings.

5. Heard the learned counsel appearing for the petitioners, the
party respondents and the learned Public Prosecutor.

6. It is submitted that the 1% petitioner and the 2™ respondent
having married, the continuance of proceedings is clear abuse of
process.

7. The learned Public Prosecutor, on instructions, submitted
that the statement of the party respondents have been recorded and
the State has no objection in terminating the proceedings as it
involves no public interest.

7. I have considered the submissions advanced.

8. In Gian Singh v. State of Punjab [(2012) 10 SCC 303]
and in Narinder Singh v. State of Punjab [(2014) 6 SCC 466], the
Apex Court has laid down that in appropriate cases, the High Court
can take note of the amicable resolution of disputes between the
victim and the wrongdoer to put an end to the criminal proceedings.

9. The offence committed by the petitioners cannot be said to
be grave and serious having ingredients of extreme mental depravity.

Bes
Cr1.MC.No. 8736 of 2018 4 2011KER/1240
It also does not appear that the offence in this case will have a serious
impact on the society. It is felt that quashing of proceedings on
account of compromise would bring about peace and secure the ends
of justice. Even otherwise, persisting with the prosecution would be
nothing, but a waste of time as the prospects of conviction is bleak.
Having considered all the relevant circumstances, I am of the
considered view that this Court will be well justified in invoking its
extraordinary powers under Section 482 of the Code to quash the
proceedings.

In the result, this petition will stand allowed. Annexure-B Final
Report and all proceedings pursuant thereto against the petitioners
now pending as S.C.No.1157 of 2013 on the file of the II Additional
Sessions Court, Thiruvananthapuram are quashed.

Sd/-
RAJA VIJAYARAGHAVAN V
JUDGE
IAP
